title: Apollo Lunar Astronauts Show Higher Cardiovascular Disease Mortality: Possible Deep Space Radiation Effects on the Vascular Endothelium
background: As spacefaring nations plan extended missions to Mars and the Moon, health risks increase when traveling beyond Earth's protective magnetosphere into intense deep space radiation environments. Previous epidemiological studies on radiation risks largely derived from low-LET radiation exposures, with limited attention to the long-term effects of space radiation on cardiovascular health.
objective: To determine whether mortality rates due to cardiovascular disease differ between non-flight astronauts, low Earth orbit astronauts, and Apollo lunar astronauts, and to investigate the mechanistic basis through animal studies of simulated space radiation effects on vascular function.
methods: Retrospective analysis of astronaut mortality data through 2015, comparing non-flight astronauts (n=35), LEO astronauts (n=35), and Apollo lunar astronauts (n=7). Animal studies used C57BL/6 mice exposed to hindlimb unloading (14 days), 1 Gy 56Fe ion irradiation, or both, with vascular function assessed 6-7 months post-treatment.
results: CVD mortality rate was 43% in Apollo lunar astronauts compared to 9% in non-flight and 11% in LEO astronauts. Animal studies showed that space-relevant irradiation induced sustained vascular endothelial dysfunction mediated through impaired NO signaling and increased oxidative stress via xanthine oxidase upregulation.
conclusion: Deep space travel beyond Earth's magnetosphere is associated with significantly higher cardiovascular disease mortality, likely due to space radiation-induced vascular endothelial dysfunction that persists long-term and may contribute to atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease development.

learning_notes.note: Apollo lunar astronauts showed a 43% cardiovascular disease mortality rate, which is 4-5 times higher than non-flight (9%) and LEO astronauts (11%), suggesting deep space travel beyond Earth's magnetosphere poses unique cardiovascular risks not encountered in low Earth orbit missions.

Animal studies demonstrated that simulated space radiation (1 Gy 56Fe ions) caused sustained vascular endothelial dysfunction that persisted 6-7 months post-exposure, equivalent to approximately 18-20 human years, through impaired nitric oxide signaling and increased oxidative stress via xanthine oxidase upregulation.

The study used non-flight astronauts as a novel reference population, addressing limitations of previous studies that compared astronauts to general populations with different baseline health characteristics, providing more accurate assessment of spaceflight-specific health risks.

Despite similar estimated galactic cosmic ray exposure doses between LEO (0.29 cGy) and Apollo astronauts (0.295 cGy), qualitative differences in radiation composition due to Earth's magnetosphere deflecting lighter particles may explain the differential CVD mortality rates observed.

Hindlimb unloading alone showed no persistent effect on vascular function, indicating that the sustained vascular endothelial dysfunction observed was primarily radiation-mediated rather than due to weightlessness or an interaction between the two factors.

The radiation exposure in animal studies (1 Gy single dose at 10 cGy/min) was higher and faster than Apollo astronauts experienced (average 0.59 cGy total dose), highlighting the need for more representative exposure paradigms in future research.

Visual light flashes experienced by Apollo astronauts (~17/hour) provided direct evidence of HZE cosmic ray traversal through retinal tissue, demonstrating that astronauts were exposed to biologically damaging high-LET radiation during deep space missions.
